text: I wouldn’t be afraid of repeating yourself or revisiting topics you’ve covered previously. Doing a newsletter for 3-4 years means that there’s a bunch of stuff that you covered in year 1+2 that folks that joined in year 3+4 would find useful. Revisiting old content also allows you to update it to reflect new thinking or new examples based on the work you’ve done since you originally wrote about the topic.

text: Hey all. I'm curious about how brand content marketers organize customer examples in their content. Specifically, if you use a customer as an example in a piece of content and then they churn, do you have a process in place to replace them? Does it matter? Do you leave it? (I understand the need to refresh case studies if someone churns, but for standard blog content, I'm wondering...)

elements.text: Hey all. I'm curious about how brand content marketers organize customer examples in their content. Specifically, if you use a customer as an example in a piece of content and then they churn, do you have a process in place to replace them? Does it matter? Do you leave it? (I understand the need to refresh case studies if someone churns, but for standard blog content, I'm wondering...)

text: I typically leave it unless I’m directed to remove the client from all marketing, which sometimes happens.

elements.text: I typically leave it unless I’m directed to remove the client from all marketing, which sometimes happens.

text: If I have the bandwidth to swap out for another story, I’ll do that as well. But it’s not always possible.

elements.text: If I have the bandwidth to swap out for another story, I’ll do that as well. But it’s not always possible.

text: <@U01KH3P18RZ> this is really interesting. Have you used it before?

elements.text: this is really interesting. Have you used it before?

text:
<@U01KGTNFLVA> Yup! I took is in ~2014. It — no joke — was a rocket ship for my business. Immediately helped me understand my target market at the time (Shopify stores), speak their language, create content, and launch services.

Then in ~2016 I pivoted to a ‘marketing skills for indies + freelancers’ focus and it helped understand the market, grow the list, create content (daily emails! podcast), and launch 13 paid information products.

30x500 is truly a super power. It is without exaggeration the best ROI I’ve ever had on a course and one of the best ROIs I’ve ever had on a business purchase.

I’ll sing 30x500, Stacking the Bricks, and Amy Hoy/Alex Hillman’s praises until the cows come home. It is _that_ good.

elements.text:

30x500 is truly a super power. It is without exaggeration the best ROI I’ve ever had on a course and one of the best ROIs I’ve ever had on a business purchase.

I’ll sing 30x500, Stacking the Bricks, and Amy Hoy/Alex Hillman’s praises until the cows come home. It is
that
good.

text: :thinking_face: Do you mean, specifically, Scrum?  For context, I spent many, many years as a software engineer and then as a consultant at enterprises that were undergoing agile transformations.  So I've seen agile in the software world from many angles.

elements.text: Do you mean, specifically, Scrum?  For context, I spent many, many years as a software engineer and then as a consultant at enterprises that were undergoing agile transformations.  So I've seen agile in the software world from many angles.

text: And I'm not asking about this to be pedantic, but because a lot of agile methodologies (e.g. extreme programming) involve things that are really not portable outside of the software world.

elements.text: And I'm not asking about this to be pedantic, but because a lot of agile methodologies (e.g. extreme programming) involve things that are really not portable outside of the software world.

text: But scrum is... ish.  Daily standups, story points and sizing, sprints, etc.  I'd think a lean/Kanban approach would make more sense for something like content, but I suppose Scrum could work, particularly if you had a lot of content where the scope/length wasn't obvious up-front

elements.text: But scrum is... ish.  Daily standups, story points and sizing, sprints, etc.  I'd think a lean/Kanban approach would make more sense for something like content, but I suppose Scrum could work, particularly if you had a lot of content where the scope/length wasn't obvious up-front

Hey <@U01L4J2LC23>, I couldn't find any examples I just really love. For our team, I created some standard questions everyone answers, then a handful of department-specific ones. I'm thinking just a colorful and fun introduction, followed by standard Q&A interview format with images sprinkled in. Nothing too fancy.
